sections.title: The End of Tobit and His Legacy

verses.text: So ended Tobit’s words of praise.
verses.comment: This verse marks the end of Tobit's hymn—a concluding doxology typical in Jewish prayer, showing Tobit's persistent faith and gratitude to God despite his hardships (cf. Psalm 34:1).
verses.sectionHeader: The End of Tobit and His Legacy

verses.text: Tobit died in peace when he was one hundred twelve years old, and was buried with great honor in Nineveh. He was sixty-two years old when he lost his eyesight, and after regaining it he lived in prosperity, giving alms and continually blessing God and acknowledging God’s majesty.
verses.comment: Tobit's long life and peaceful death reflect divine blessing, while the emphasis on his almsgiving and worship illustrates the ideal of righteousness in Jewish wisdom literature (cf. Sirach 3:3).

verses.text: When he was dying, he called his son Tobias and the seven sons of Tobias, and instructed him:
verses.comment: Tobit’s instructions echo the practice of handing on the faith and moral teaching across generations, much like the patriarchs of Israel (e.g., Gen. 49).

verses.text: and hurry off to Media, for I believe the word of God that Nahum spoke about Nineveh, that all these things will take place and overtake Assyria and Nineveh. Indeed, everything that was spoken by the prophets of Israel, whom God sent, will occur. None of all their words will fail, but all will come true at their appointed times. So it will be safer in Media than in Assyria and Babylon. For I know and believe that whatever God has said will be fulfilled and will come true; not a single word of the prophecies will fail. All of our kindred, inhabitants of the land of Israel, will be scattered and taken as captives from the good land; and the whole land of Israel will be desolate, even Samaria and Jerusalem will be desolate. And the temple of God in it will be burned to the ground, and it will be desolate for a while.
verses.comment: Tobit’s advice to seek safety in Media invokes belief in prophetic authority and underscores themes of exile, judgment, and trust in God's word, echoing prophecies like Nahum’s oracle against Nineveh (Nahum 1–3) and the destruction foretold by other prophets (Jeremiah 7:34; Micah 3:12).

verses.text: But God will again have mercy on them, and God will bring them back into the land of Israel; and they will rebuild the temple of God, though not like the first one until the time of fulfillment comes. After this, they will all return from their exile and will rebuild Jerusalem in splendor, and in it the temple of God will be rebuilt, just as the prophets of Israel have foretold.
verses.comment: Tobit’s final exhortation stresses obedience to the law and mercy—two pillars that later become central in Christian ethical teaching (Matt. 22:37-40).

verses.text: Then the nations in the whole world will all be converted and worship God in truth. They will all abandon their idols, which deceitfully have led them into their error;
verses.comment: Reference to the temple’s future glory hints at a messianic age and the eschatological gathering of God’s people. The prophecy foreshadows Christ’s establishment of the new and everlasting covenant (Heb. 9:11-12).

verses.text: and in righteousness they will praise the eternal God. All the Israelites who are saved in those days and are truly mindful of God will be gathered together; they will go to Jerusalem and live in safety forever in the land of Abraham, and it will be given over to them. Those who sincerely love God will rejoice, but those who commit sin and injustice will vanish from all the earth.
verses.comment: Anticipation of all nations worshiping the one true God prefigures the universality of the Gospel and God’s plan to unite Jew and Gentile in worship (Rom. 11:17-18).

verses.text: So now, my children, I command you, serve God faithfully and do what is pleasing in his sight. Command your children to do what is right and to give alms, and to always remember God and bless his name sincerely and with all their strength. So now, my son, leave Nineveh; do not remain here.
verses.comment: Universal praise of God by every nation is both a prophetic glimpse and a summons for God’s people to holiness, setting the stage for worldwide communion in worship.

verses.text: On whatever day you bury your mother beside me, do not remain overnight within the boundaries of the city. For I see that there is much wickedness in it, and much deceit is practiced there, and the people are unashamed. Consider, my son, what Nadab did to Ahikar who raised him: was he not, while still alive, brought down into the earth? For God repaid him for his shameful treatment. Ahikar came again into the light, but Nadab went into everlasting darkness because he tried to kill Ahikar. Because Ahikar gave alms, he escaped the deadly trap that Nadab set for him, but Nadab fell into it himself and was destroyed.
verses.comment: Tobit illustrates the eventual justice of God against the unfaithful. The warning shows that the righteous are sometimes afflicted, but ultimate vindication belongs to those who persevere.

verses.text: So now, my children, see what almsgiving accomplishes, and what injustice does—it brings death! But now my breath fails me.” Then they laid him on his bed, and he died; and he received an honorable funeral.
verses.comment: Reiteration of almsgiving’s power points to the connection between faith and works, a theme echoed in Christ’s teaching (Matt. 25:34-40). This interweaving of charity and salvation is a foundation for understanding Christian righteousness.

verses.text: When Tobias’s mother died, he buried her beside his father. Then he and his wife and his children returned to Media and settled in Ecbatana with Raguel, his father-in-law.
verses.comment: Moral choices have spiritual consequences, echoing the biblical teaching that sin ultimately leads to ruin.

verses.text: He treated his parents-in-law with great respect in their old age, and buried them in Ecbatana of Media. He inherited both the property of Raguel and that of his father Tobit.
verses.comment: The honorable burial underscores the importance of caring for the dead, a practice regarded as a work of mercy in Christian tradition.

verses.text: He died highly respected at the age of one hundred seventeen years.
verses.comment: The inheritance and respect for family point to the biblical pattern of generational blessing, stewardship, and the honoring of parents (Ex. 20:12).

verses.text: Before he died he heard of the destruction of Nineveh, and he saw its prisoners being led into Media, those whom King Cyaxares of Media had taken captive. Tobias praised God for all he had done to the people of Nineveh and Assyria; before he died he rejoiced over Nineveh, and he blessed the Lord God forever and ever. Amen.
verses.comment: Tobias witnesses Nineveh’s downfall as prophesied, reinforcing the fulfillment of God’s word; his praise reflects a Jewish perspective on divine justice and sovereignty over nations (cf. Daniel 2:21, Isaiah 10:5–19).
